raw_text:
FBI agent colludes with analyst
 
 A former FBI agent and an internet stock picker have been found guilty of using confidential US government information to manipulate stock prices.
 
 A New York court ruled that former FBI man Jeffrey Royer, 41, fed damaging information to Anthony Elgindy, 36. Mr Elgindy then drove share prices lower by spreading negative publicity via his newsletter. The Egyptian-born analyst would extort money from his targets in return for stopping the attacks, prosecutors said. "Under the guise of protecting investors from fraud, Royer and Elgindy used the FBI's crime-fighting tools and resources actually to defraud the public," said US Attorney Roslynn Mauskopf.
 
 Mr Royer was convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice and witness tampering. Mr Elgindy was convicted of racketeering, securities fraud and extortion.
 
 The charges carry sentences of up to 20 years. When the guilty verdict was announced by the jury foreman, Mr Elgindy dropped his face into his hands and sobbed, the Associated Press news agency reported. He was led weeping from the court room by US marshals, AP said. Defense lawyers contended that Mr Royer had been feeding information to Mr Elgindy and another trader in an attempt to expose corporate fraud. Mr Elgindy's team claimed that he also was fighting against corporate wrongdoing. "Elgindy's conviction marks the end of his public charade as a crusader against fraud in the market," said Ms Mauskopf. One of the more bizarre aspects of the trial focused on the claims that Mr Elgindy may have had foreknowledge of the 11 September terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. Mr Elgindy had been trying to sell stock prior to the attack and had predicted a slump in the market. No charges were brought in relation to these allegations.
llama3.2:1b: A former FBI agent, Jeffrey Royer, was found guilty of colluding with an internet stock picker, Anthony Elgindy, to manipulate stock prices using confidential government information.
Elgindy would spread negative publicity through his newsletter to drive down share prices and extort money from his targets in return for stopping corporate wrongdoing.
llama3.2:3b: A former FBI agent, Jeffrey Royer, and an internet analyst, Anthony Elgindy, were found guilty of using confidential information to manipulate stock prices.
They were convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, and extortion.
The case involved a scheme where Royer provided damaging information to Elgindy, who then spread negative publicity to drive down share prices in exchange for money.
gemma2:2b: A former FBI agent, Jeffrey Royer, colluded with an internet stock picker, Anthony Elgindy, to manipulate stock prices using confidential US government information.
Both were convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, and other charges.
The scheme involved spreading negative publicity about companies to drive down their share prices for profit.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Former FBI agent Jeffrey Royer fed damaging information to Anthony Elgindy, who used his newsletter to drive share prices lower by spreading negative publicity.
Royer was convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice and witness tampering.
He received a sentence of up to 20 years in prison.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A former FBI agent and internet analyst manipulated stock prices using confidential government information, extorting money from targets for negative publicity.
The case resulted in convictions for racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and witness tampering.
qwen2.5:3b: A former FBI agent, Jeffrey Royer, and an analyst, Anthony Elgindy, have been found guilty of using confidential US government information to manipulate stock prices.
Royer provided damaging intel to Elgindy, who then spread negative news via his newsletter to lower share prices.
Prosecutors claimed Elgindy extorted money from targets for silence.
Both were convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, and other charges with potential sentences up to 20 years.
Upon hearing the verdict, Elgindy cried and was escorted out by US marshals.
Defense argued Elgindy fought corporate wrongdoing, but prosecutors disputed this, focusing instead on their claims about prior knowledge of September 11 attacks unrelated to stock manipulation.
opencoder:1.5b:
FBI agent collude with analyst

A former FBI agent and an internet stock picker have been found guilty of using confidential US government information to manipulate stock prices.
Two individuals have both been found guilty of violations of a criminal code, including racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and witness tampering.

Prosecutors said that the former FBI agent used FBI crime-fighting tools and resources that he had intentionally used to defraud the public, while the latter was extorted from his targets with money in return for stopping the attacks.
The charges carry up to 20 years sentence.
When the guilty verdict was announced by the jury foreman, Mr Elgindy sobbed, the Associated Press reported.
He was led weeping from the court room by US marshals.
Defense lawyer contended that Mr Royer had indeed been feeding information on another trader and he also attempted to defraud corporate fraud.
Mr Elgindy's team claimed that he also committed other fraudulent activities.

"Elgindy's conviction marks the end of his public charade as a crusader against fraud in the market," said Ms Mauskopf, who had publicly expressed her concerns about Mr Royer's use of confidential information.
smollm:1.7b: The FBI agent colludes with the analyst, using confidential US government information to manipulate stock prices.
The former FBI man Jeffrey Royer, 41, fed damaging information to Anthony Elgindy, 36.
Mr Elgindy then drove share prices lower by spreading negative publicity via his newsletter.
The Egyptian-born analyst would extort money from his targets in return for stopping the attacks, prosecutors said.
"Under the guise of protecting investors from fraud, Royer and Elgindy used the FBI's crime-fighting tools and resources actually to defraud the public," said US Attorney Roslynn Mauskopf.
The charges carry sentences of up to 20 years.
When the guilty verdict was announced by the jury foreman, Mr Elgindy dropped his face into his hands and sobbed, the Associated Press news agency reported.
He was led weeping from the court room by US marshals, AP said.
Defense lawyers contended that Mr Royer had been feeding information to Mr Elgindy and another trader in an attempt to expose corporate fraud.
Mr Elgindy's team claimed that he also was fighting against corporate wrongdoing.
"Elgindy's conviction marks the end of his public charade as a crusader against fraud in the market," said Ms Mauskopf.
No charges were brought in relation to these allegations.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: A former FBI agent, Jeffrey Royer, and an internet stock picker, Anthony Elgindy, were found guilty of manipulating stock prices using confidential US government information.
Royer fed damaging information into Elgindy, who then used his newsletter to drive lower prices by making negative remarks.

The court ruled that Mr. Royer was convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and witness tampering, while Mr. Elgindy was convicted of racketeering and securities fraud but acquitted himself.
The verdict carried up to 20 years.
When the jury heard Elgindy drop his hands and sob, they were led from the court room by marshals, reporting his struggle and claiming he was fighting against corporate fraud.
His team accused him of opposing corporate wrongdoing.
The trial also noted possible knowledge of the 11/9/2001 attacks, though no charges were filed for these claims.
tinyllama:1.1b: An FBI agent and an internet stock picker, Jeffrey Royer and Anthony Elgindy, have been found guilty of using confidential US government information to manipulate share prices, leading to fraudulent attacks on corporate wrongdoing and a loss of investor confidence.

The former FBI man was convicted of racketeering, fraud, obstruction of justice and extortion, while the latter was found guilty of racketeering, fraud, extortion, obstruction of justice and witness tampering.
Both men were sentenced to 20 years in prison for their alleged crimes.
The trial exposed the extent of Mr Elgindy's efforts to expose corporate wrongdoing, and his own attempts to profit from it.
It also highlighted the absurdity of his claims that he had learned about the attacks beforehand.
The charges carry sentences of up to 20 years for each conviction.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, the US FBI and an internet stock picker named Anthony Elgindy have been found guilty of using confidential US government information to manipulate stock prices.
The pair fed damaging information to their analyst Jeffrey Royer, who then spread negative publicity via his newsletter to drive down the prices of his targets.
This trial was part of a larger investigation into fraudulent stock trading in the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).
phi:2.7b: A former FBI agent and an internet stock picker, Jeffrey Royer and Anthony Elgindy, have been found guilty of manipulating stock prices using confidential US government information.
They spread negative publicity via Anthony's newsletter to extort money from their targets in return for stopping the attacks.
The charges carry up to 20 years' imprisonment, with Mr Elgindy crying when the verdict was announced as he dropped his hands into his face.
Defense lawyers argued that Mr Royer was trying to expose corporate fraud while Mr Elgindy claimed he was fighting against it.

One of the more bizarre aspects of the trial focused on allegations that Mr Elgindy may have had foreknowledge of the 11 September terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, but no charges were brought in relation to these claims.
orca-mini:3b: A former FBI agent colluded with an internet stock picker to manipulate stock prices by using confidential US government information to feed damaging information to an analyst who would drive share prices lower through negative publicity.

They used the FBI's crime-fighting tools and resources to defraud the public, and when found guilty, the former FBI agent was sentenced to 20 years in prison while the internet stock picker received a lesser sentence of 8 years.

However, there were also allegations that the analyst may have had foreknowledge of the 11 September terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, but no charges were brought in relation to these allegations.
hermes3:3b: FBI agent and analyst guilty of using confidential info to manipulate stock prices by spreading negative publicity, extorting money for stopping attacks on investors, facing up to 20-year sentences.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Two men, an FBI agent and an internet stock picker, have been found guilty of using confidential government information to manipulate stock prices for personal gain.
Jeffrey Royer fed damaging information to Anthony Elgindy, who then spread negative publicity to lower share prices and extort money from victims.
Both were convicted of various offenses, with potential sentences of up to 20 years.
The trial focused on claims that Elgindy may have had foreknowledge of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, but no charges related to this were brought.

Royer provided damaging information to Elgindy, who then spread negative publicity to drive share prices down and extorted money from companies to stop the attacks.
Both were convicted of racketeering and securities fraud, with Elgindy also guilty of extortion and Royer of obstruction of justice and witness tampering.
They face up to 20 years in prison.
Prosecutors said they misused FBI resources to defraud the public, while the defense argued they were exposing corporate fraud.
The trial also included claims that Elgindy may have had foreknowledge of the 9/11 attacks, but no charges were filed regarding this allegation.
stablelm2:1.6b: FBI agent Jeffrey Royer and internet analyst Anthony Elgindy were found guilty of using confidential US government information to manipulate stock prices.
They were convicted on racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and witness tampering charges.
Defense lawyers argued that Royer was trying to expose corporate fraud, while Elgindy claimed he was fighting against it.
No charges related to the September 2001 terrorist attacks were brought in relation to these allegations.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Former FBI agent Jeffrey Royer, 41, and internet stock analyst Anthony Elgindy, 36, were found guilty of using confidential FBI information to manipulate stock prices.
Royer provided damaging data to Elgindy, who then spread negative news via his newsletter to drive down share prices.
Prosecutors alleged that Elgindy extorted money from targets in exchange for halting the attacks.

Both were convicted of racketeering, securities fraud, obstruction of justice, and witness tampering; Royer additionally faced a charge of obstruction of justice due to allegedly trying to interfere with an FBI investigation.
Their convictions carry up to 20 years in prison.
Elgindy wept upon hearing the verdict, while defense lawyers argued Royer intended to expose corporate fraud rather than defraud investors.
A notable aspect of the trial was the claim that Elgindy had foreknowledge of the 9/11 attacks, though no charges were filed regarding this allegation.
